Method: Population dataset created from an extensive literature search. Incorporates different sources to create national population trend.

Citation: Brambilla, A. et al. (2020) Distribution, status, and recent population dynamics of Alpine ibex Capra ibex in Europe, Mammal Review, 50(3), pp. 267277. doi: 10.1111/mam.12194.
Method: Data gathered from requests to management authorities and from published literature. Management authorities survey methods include block counts where areas occupied by each colony are divided into sectors then expert observers count individuals from vantage points. Usually efforts are made to coordinate counts with neighbouring authorities to avoid double counting. This count data was then modelled to give population estimates.

Citation: Conroy, J. W. H., Yoxon, P. and Gutleb, A. C. (eds) (2000) Proceedings of the First Otter Toxicology Conference: Isle of Skye, September 2000, in. Broadford, Isle of Skye, Scotland: International Otter Survival Fund.
Units: Estimated number of individuals per 10 km of river bank
Method: During the winter the river banks, ice covers and floodplains were searched for tracks. Prints of the hind feet were measured and differences of footprints of single otters consistently >1cm were accepted as criterion for differentiating individuals. Scats and urine marks were also examined to determine sex. This data is used to estimate density.

Citation: Heltai, M. (2012) Changes in the occurrence and population trend of the Eurasian otter (Lutra lutra) in Hungary between 1990 and 2006, North-Western Journal of Zoology, 8(1), pp. 112118.
Units: Estimated number of individuals per 1000 hectares
Method: Data on otter distribution and occurrence were collected annually by mail questionnaires to Game Management Units (GMUs). Density was estimated over the GMUs and the whole country using grid cells.

Citation: Ruiz-Olmo, J. et al. (2011) Factors affecting otter (Lutra lutra) abundance and breeding success in freshwater habitats of the northeastern Iberian Peninsula, European Journal of Wildlife Research, 57(4), pp. 827842. doi: 10.1007/s10344-011-0495-0.
Method: Visual censuses using a standardised method where observers positioned at regular distances along riverbanks recorded otter movement in spring/summer.

Citation: Sidorovich, V. E., Krasko, D. A. and Dyman, A. A. (2005) Landscape-related differences in diet, food supply and distribution pattern of the pine marten, Martes martes in the transitional mixed forest of northern Belarus, Folia Zoologica, 54(12), pp. 3952.
Location: Woodland in a clay area (300km2 in size) on the upper reaches of the Lovat river, Gorodok district, Vitebsk region, north-eastern Belarus
Units: Average number of trails per 1 km per day
Method: Trail counts along standard routes were carried out twice each winter in a variety of habitats, once at the beginning of the snowy period (usually by late November or early December) and once at the end of snowy period (usually in March). Abundance was calculated as the number of the species trails crossing the route divided by the number of kilometres inspected and the number of days passed since the last snowfall. The resulting number is the average number of trails per 1 km transect per day.

Citation: Sidorovich, V. E., Krasko, D. A. and Dyman, A. A. (2005) Landscape-related differences in diet, food supply and distribution pattern of the pine marten, Martes martes in the transitional mixed forest of northern Belarus, Folia Zoologica, 54(12), pp. 3952.

Citation: Corlatti, L. et al. (2019) Long?term dynamics of Alpine ungulates suggest interspecific competition, Journal of Zoology, 309(4), pp. 241249. doi: 10.1111/jzo.12716.
Method: Block counts are used to survey chamois in open areas and involve simultaneous counting of animals from vantage points or trails, using natural features (e.g. ridges and valleys) to define sampling units. Each year, in July, 2 park rangers, forest rangers or game wardens per unit simultaneously searched for chamois between 6.00 and 9.00 AM with optical instruments. The chamois survey area extended over 13 400 ha above the treeline and included 37 sampling units. The total number of chamois recorded yearly across all sampling units was used as the population size. The potential for double counting was reduced by communicating chamois movements between adjacent units.
